Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A High resolution Paleontological, Ichnological, and Chemostratigraphic Study of Late Devonian Mass Extinctions
Award.AbstractNarration:
RUI, Collaborative Research: A High resolution Paleontological, Ichnological, and Chemostratigraphic Study of Late Devonian Mass Extinctions

by
Diana Boyer, EAR-1348981, SUNY Oswego
Gordon Love, EAR-1348988, Univ. California, Riverside

ABSTRACT
The rock record preserves a detailed history of past events in life history, and understanding these events, particularly episodes of unusual biotic turnover, is of paramount importance, particularly in this time of our current diversity crises. There have been many large scale extinction events throughout geologic history, and despite extensive study, the Late Devonian mass extinction events in the Frasnian-Famennian still remain enigmatic in terms of a causal mechanism. Although numerous kill mechanisms have been proposed, marine anoxia is widely thought to be a major contributing factor, in part because of the pervasiveness of organic-rich black shale. This study will test for extensive anoxic and/or pervasive euxinic (sulfidic water column) conditions associated with several biotic turnover events preserved in a Laurentian basin. PIs will use an integrated paleontological, inorganic geochemical, and lipid biomarker approach performed at high spatial resolution to reconstruct secular changes in ancient microbial and metazoan source organism inputs, and marine redox structure in these ancient epeiric seaways. They will test for a correlation between the magnitude and timing of extinction events and patterns of oxygen and euxinic stress which prevailed.
The utility of combining paleontological and geochemical proxies to recognize bottom water oxygen levels on a fine-scale in black shale facies has been realized (Boyer et al., 2011), but not yet applied to understand the dynamics of major events in the history of life. The new light we are shedding on Late Devonian biospheric and environmental evolution in North America will inform and direct future work in biogeochemistry, paleontology/paleobiology, evolutionary biology, and ocean-atmosphere evolution. Central to this research is a unique bridging of organic and inorganic geochemical methods with paleontology within a broad field-based template to yield high-resolution bio- and chemostratigraphic records that span the Late Devonian mass extinction events and their aftermath. At the heart of this research proposal is the training and education of a group of talented graduate, undergraduate and K-12 school students in the geosciences at UCR and SUNY Oswego, many from underrepresented ethnic groups, through a combination of direct involvement in the research project or through a variety of outreach ventures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through this investigation, we generated detailed and informative chemostratigraphic records for a large suite sedimentary rocks which were deposited in ancient epicontinental seaways during the Late Devonian period (ca. 355-380 Myr) in the Appalachian Basin.  Our investigation utilized an integrated paleontological, inorganic geochemical, and lipid biomarker approach to reconstruct secular changes in ancient biota, carbon and nitrogen biogechemical cycling and marine chemistry conditions that offer new inisghts into the environmental and ecological stability spanning two of the Late Devonian mass extinction events (the Upper Kellwasser Event and the Hangenberg Crisis). Our lipid biomarker work at UCR involved detailed interrogation of biomarker assemblages using the latest Metastable Reaction Monitoring-Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry methods developed in-house. Lipid biomarker assemblages from the sedimentary rocks were abundant, diverse and demonstrably endogenous to the host rocks.  Thus, the lipid biomarker evidence preserved important biogeochemical information and unique insights concerning the stability ancient marine communities and paleoenvironmental conditions of oxygen stress which prevailed prior to and through these extinction intervals.  Ultimately, we helped provide new insights into the stability of marine paleoenvironmental conditions and biological community structure which prevailed and assessed possible drivers for mass extinction pulses in the Late Devonian period.

Our multiproxy evidence for variable marine redox environmental conditions through the Upper Kellwasser event in NY state challenges the notion of a global mechanism of euxinic stress (toxic sulfidic conditions in the water column) which has been previously proposed  for this extinction event. Additionally, we have better defined the peak expression of the younger Hangenberg biotic crisis in Ohio and the environmental context for deposition for black shales during this interval. Deposition of the Hangenberg black shale sequence in Ohio occurred locally under predominantly euxinic (sulfidic) marine conditions, with evidence obtained for an expanding oxygen mimimum zone and strengthening denitrification acting as important negative feedback mechanisms for curtailing high local primary productivity. A paradox relating to Late Devonian geobiology that we uncovered from our entire investigation is that marine microbial communities remained stable and productive through extended episodes associated with mass extinctions of marine invertebrate animals; indeed, it was this rich marine productivity that locally sustained oxygen minimum zones in the marine water column that were environmentally harmful to the fauna.  Our unique bridging of organic and inorganic geochemical methods with paleontology, within a broad field-based template, has shed new light, on Paleozoic biospheric and environmental evolution. Our findings will inform and direct future work in geochemistry, petroleum geosciences, paleobiology, evolutionary biology and ocean-atmosphere evolution.

The project has allowed for research training opportunities for two UCR graduate students (Rosemarie Bisquera and Aaron Martinez) and one promising UCR undergraduate student (Cecilia Lopez) from traditionally underrepresented ethic groups in the geosciences.  Rosemarie Bisquera graduated with a Masters degree in Summer of 2016 and Aaron Martinez has gone on to pursue a PhD degree in organic geochemistry at UCR.
